course.subject: MATH
course.name: Combinatorial Analysis
course.description: An introduction to combinatorics: What is combinatorics? Permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, generating permutations and combinations, pigeonhole principle, Ramsey theory, inclusion-exclusion principle, rook polynomials, linear recurrence relations, nonhomogeneous linear recurrence relations of the first and second order, generating functions, Catalan numbers, Stirling numbers, partition numbers, matchings and stable matchings, systems of distinctive representatives, block designs, Steiner triple systems, Latin squares, Burnside's lemma, Polya counting formula.
course.prerequisites: MATH 2121/MATH 2111/MATH 2350/MATH 2131; or MATH 2343/COMP 2711

reviews.author: I love ust <3<3
reviews.comment_content:
The syllabus on his website is not accurate, here is the syllabus in 2019 Spring.
But the instructor said he is going to change the content of this course, I don't know whether the following is still applicable.

1. Perfect Cover; Game of Nim
2. Pigeon Hole Principle, Ramsey Theorem
3. Permutations and Combinations
4. Algorithms for Generating Permutation and Combinations; Partially Ordered Sets
5. Binomial Coefficients
6. Inclusion-Exclusion Principle (on Linear Ordered Sets)
-------------------Midterm-------------------
7. Mobius Function, Mobius Inversion
8. Recurrence Relations and Generating Functions
9. Special Counting Sequence: Difference Operator; Stirling Number
10. Marriage Problem

In general, this course covered lots of things, but usually they are uncorrelated, so the midterm and final is not cumulative.

The topics are quite funny for me and some of them are useful like the Recurrence Relations and Generating Functions.
Though some the topics are not that useful if you are not in the Pure Math Track, but this course essentially makes you more mature mathematically.

Prof Chen also always mentioned Machine Learning stuffs during lectures, I guess the topics are somehow related to CS application, like the Graph Theory.
He also added a bit to this course from his research topics which you cannot find it in the textbook.

Anyway, the course content can be organized in a better way.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I skipped most of the lectures since 10:30am is too early for me.

Most of the contents are trivial according to Prof Chen, he usually goes through his lecture notes during lectures like other professors from the MATH department. For some abstract concepts, he would give intuitive ideas to explain.

During the lectures before the midterm and final exam, Prof Chen will ask what kind of questions and which topic that we want them to be appeared in the exam paper, he will then decide the exam coverage in these 2 lectures, just attend this 2 lectures is enough for this course I think.
And the exam questions are indeed what he mentioned in the class, he is really kind.

reviews.author: kkkph1
reviews.comment_content:
The content for this course is the following:
1. Introduction
2. Pigeonhole principle and Ramsey theory
3. Permutations and combinations
4. Generating permutations and combinations, posets
5. Binomial coefficients and Dilworth theorem
6. Inclusion exclusion, Mobius inversion (the densest chapter)
7. Recurrency relation and generating functions
8. Special counting sequences
9. Matchings in bipartite graphs and System of distinct representatives

The topics are quite interesting and useful if you are interested in combinatorics or theoretical computer science.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Chen focuses greatly on theory for this course. His lecture style for this course is to go ever and explain some parts of the notes that he made. Prof. Chen's notes are very thorough and contain many proofs for different theorems. I recommend reading them before going to the lecture so you can understand the lecture much better. Personally, I can only understand 50~60% of the lecture if I don't read the notes in advance. Sometimes he would just skip some parts of the notes because it takes time for you to read and understand the proof and it is a waste of time to go over it in lecture.
